Do Mormons have a temple in their home?

We do not have temples in our homes, but we do consider our homes to be sacred places where families can grow in love and truth and knowledge.

Any structure in which these activities take place can be a “temple” of sorts. We even consider our bodies to be the temple of our spiritual selves, where the eternal essence of us can learn to love God and our neighbors— the two great commandments.

However, as has been said, our homes and our meeting houses are distinct from our temple buildings in purpose and function. But all three are sacred places.

Why is attending the temple an important part of Mormon worship?

Original question: Why is attending the temple an important part of Mormon worship?

Members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints believe that important ordinances can only be performed in the temple, such as proxy baptisms for ancestors who did not have the opportunity to be baptized and eternal marriages. Members also make important covenants with God in the temple, such as a covenant to be chaste and to obediently sacrifice and consecrate your time, talents, and everything you possess to build up the Kingdom of God on the earth.

In the temple, Church members receive these ordinan

Original question: Why is attending the temple an important part of Mormon worship?

Members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints believe that important ordinances can only be performed in the temple, such as proxy baptisms for ancestors who did not have the opportunity to be baptized and eternal marriages. Members also make important covenants with God in the temple, such as a covenant to be chaste and to obediently sacrifice and consecrate your time, talents, and everything you possess to build up the Kingdom of God on the earth.

In the temple, Church members receive these ordinances and covenants, along with other lectures, knowledge, and blessings, in preparation for the life to come in the Celestial Kingdom of God.

In other words, the temple helps and teaches us to live a more holy life in preparation for eternal life with Jesus.

Do you believe in astrology, and why or why not?

I never used to believe in Astrology and would hate it when my parents would follow it. But as life is unpredictable, I ended up believing in it and became one of those. Below is my story:

I often come across this question from my friends in a very astonishing way, “How come you into Astrology?,” as I had mocked everyone who ever talked about astrology. However, today I can share my journey with everyone.

Back in 2013, I quit my job with Nomura to pursue my dreams but things didn’t go as planned and I struggled for a year and exhausted my savings. To make ends meet, I went back to Mumbai and did some odd jobs as I was not getting shortlisted for any technology job interviews, citing a gap of one year. After some networking, an old colleague referred me to BNP Paribas and I got the job at a pay cut.

After working there for a year, I got in touch with one of my school friends, who later went to IIT Delhi, and we both planned to start an IT services company. It was time to put down the papers yet again, and I typed the resignation letter with full enthusiasm (that time I didn’t have to look for email templates on Google) but I got very anxious before sending it, as the old struggling days started haunting me.

As I was staring dead at the resignation email, one of my colleagues came over and inquired, “Is everything okay? You look lost.” I showed her my resignation letter and told her how my negative thoughts are not letting me do what I wanted to.

She looked at me with empathy and said, “I can see your birth chart and tell you what to do as per Astrology. What are your birth details?” and she opened one very badly designed app on her phone to input my details. I was shocked and amused at the same time. I promised myself to hire good UI/UX designers to develop better apps than that).

“Seriously? Do you think I believe in all this? Padhe likhe hoke aap andh vishwas faila rahe ho!” I scolded her but I wished I could get some help.

She waited for me to complete and demanded, “Are you done? Now tell me your birth details. I don’t care if you believe or not but let me try to help.” I shared the details as I would rather not mess with a senior. But knowing her coding skills, I could totally judge that she would screw up in Astrology as well.

As she was analysing my chart, I waited curiously to know the outcome, the way I had waited for my 10th standard board results. There is something about Astrology, it doesn’t matter whether you believe in it or not, but it fascinates you like nothing else. However, as I didn’t trust her and would never have liked to take a biased decision based on Astrology, so I quickly sent the resignation letter and locked my screen. Meanwhile, she was done with her calculations and it was time for the results.

“You are Leo Ascendant and your Sun is exalted…” I interrupted her in between and asked, “I don’t understand all this. Tell me something about the past to make me believe you,” I was such a spoiler.

“Beta, jitna tu bhaagta hai na isse, aage jake utna jaada believe karega (Dear, as much as you are mocking this today, you will believe in it much more, in future),” She mocked me this time but after hearing that I was convinced she knew Astrology as good as Database designing, as I would never do that.

“You don’t choose Astrology, Astrology chooses you”

Then she told me many things about my past to make her point including the date of my accident in school days, which was shocking. And once she observed the change in my body language, she stopped telling about the past and came to the main question. She not only predicted the past correctly but was also such a nice observer of behaviour. Oh God! Why the hell was she a MySQL developer?

“Yes, you can quit your job as the next two years are very promising for an IT business as per the placement of Saturn and Rahu,” she smiled as she made the prediction. I am still not sure if that smile was for a positive prediction or for the virtual win over me.

“Just two years?,” I exclaimed with a sheepish laugh as I had to pretend that I was not interested.

Like every other story, this story was also filled with some twist and turns. The twist was that my business partner might leave after two years from then and I would face some issues in resuming the business and it might take a year to pivot to a new venture, “But you will make it” she assured after observing my not-so-good body language.

“You can press the send button,” she finally said something with a real smile as she observed that I wasn’t mocking anymore and had surrendered myself, unlike a Leo.

After that, I served my notice period and came to Noida and started an IT services company named CodeYeti in April 2015. We managed to scale up very quickly to 45 employees, serving about 15-20 clients at a time and clocked a revenue of $0.5 million in the first year itself. We started working for big enterprises like Yamaha, GreenPly along with startups.

Everything was going well until my partner told me that he is not getting a kick from the services business and wanted to do a tech product. We spent the next six months on two products but ended up wasting capital as nothing seemed to work and he finally quit in March 2017 to do something else.

And that reminded me about the prediction, my ex-colleague had made about my partner’s exit. I called her after a gap of two years (Let’s just assume that I was busy and was not bad at keeping in touch) and told her about the prediction.

I could sense the happiness in her voice as her prediction came true but she showed concern as it was a loss for me. To my surprise, she knew everything about CodeYeti as she followed our social media channels and congratulated me for what we had achieved in such a short duration.

“Do you want me to check your chart again?” she inquired.

I paused for a moment and proposed an idea, “How about I start a product in the field of Astrology and I become your first customer?” She halted for a few seconds and said, “Hmmm…I had quit my job four months back for some personal reasons, and I can take out some time to work with you but I won’t be very active, so you will have to find more astrologers. I can connect you with a few in my network”

“Yes Yes! You can work whenever you have time and you can interview and train other astrologers and we will keep hiring. You can become their mentor and take care of the department of Astrologers”, I said in excitement.

“Hmm…So, when are we going live?” she straight away asked for a deadline, the way she did at BNP. Some people never change.

And then, there was the ultimate turn – I worked on developing the product and launched an MVP (minimum viable product) of AstroTalk within a month and assigned a dedicated technology & operations team to it. I called her as a customer and asked, “How would AstroTalk do?”

Current stats:

Total Installs: 95,00,000+

Daily Consultations with Astrologers: 3,20,000 minutes over chat/call

Revenue: INR 70,00,000 daily

Repeat Rate: 13+ (Higher than Swiggy)

Within 4.5 years of launch, we have changed the way people interact with Astrologers and gave 20+ years old companies a run for their money. There were two basic fundamental problems with companies in this industry, which we could fix very precisely.

  • Companies were run by Astrologers who lacked technology expertise and made a very low-quality product with the worst possible customer experience.
  • Companies were run by some decent technology people (still lacked a good UI/UX design) who had no idea about how to build a business. They just focused on making money and offered no customer delight. Customer support was so poor that they had a very poor repeat rate in an industry with such high demands.

However, I feel the biggest reason we could do so well was that I never believed in Astrology as I had seen so many fake astrologers my entire life, predicting everything incorrectly, which made people like me hate the concept of Astrology.

However, after getting an accurate prediction about my partner’s exit, even before starting the partnership, I started believing in it and I realized that ‘the Astrologer could be wrong, but Astrology is always right.‘ So, I made sure we appoint the best in the list of professional Astrologer online for astrology today.

It is not easy to get a place on our panel as we have a special recruitment team that reaches out to the best Astrologer in India, and we make them go through multiple case studies and interviews, to be sure about their prediction quality and communications skills.

TL;DR:
Just as with everything else, there are two ways to look at this and two outcomes of the question. Although the reality is subjective and this cannot be answered with a yes or no, because both are equally good answers with relevant valid-real-life examples to either side.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Lets start analyzing this with Quora itself and then move on to other examples of technology.

Case 1: Quora (and of course other similar websites and forums for free information including edulix, wikipedia, XDA, reddit [bite me], twitter and other social networks too)
Good: There is high quality content on Quora, provided by users like Balaji Viswanathan (பாலாஜி விஸ்வநாதன்), Leonard Kim, Bhuvi Jain, User-12616619705513344996, Judith Meyer, Ken Nakagama, Claire J. Vannette, Ian Morgan, Dan Bradbury, Eivind and more (many I am unaware of and some who I don't follow yet). Contributing answers for topics and fields from economics, politics, religion, technology, start ups and entrepreneurship, relationship advices, food and cuisines, languages and culture and what not. For each question, in most cases, the top 20 answers will cover almost everything there is to know about it-- high quality. On edulix aspiring students can get free profile evaluations for the probability of their candidacy at their dream institutions of advanced studies.

Bad:- Sadly some people who just want to get popular/upvotes/I-dont-know-what answer to a question which already has good answers without contributing to the knowledge pool or adding any quality to it.

A truck load lot of questions on relationships and dating problems (mostly coming from Indian demographic) are getting repeatedly asked; new questions even if the same has been asked in just another set of words.
Not completely bad in itself but people need to be a tad more patient and diligent in looking for answers- chances are someone else has been where you are and someone else has treaded that area successfully. Look for it.

Don't multi-post if you're not adding quality to the content and only quantity.

A lot of questions and answers which are biased, especially if related to religion and politics; similar to how most of the journos and media personnel who prefer to provide *spiced* and *sensational* news reports, rather than facts, which ends up reducing the quality.

Case 2:- Smartphones (or cellphones in general)
These are definitely good, when you use it for communication and learning from it. good

bad:- if you are glued to your phone 24*7 playing games and texting friends, trying to hook up with online dating while there are people (some family, your colleagues and friends) right in front of you. You may be an introvert and prefer to be in isolation (in your own world and alone) which is okay.

Case 3: Laptop-Tablets-Computers. Even Television
very similar to smartphones, you could actually just combine the two as one case. Use them to read, study, watch encyclopedias, articles and shoes of National Geographic, Discovery etc and its good. Watch only movies and play games, you're wasting your time.

Case 4: Automobiles
Good: helps you move around with your family in comfort and travel on your own time. When you carpool. Useful (especially in Europe where trains are generally the expensive transportation method) to travel longer distances from one city to another, because it ends up being cheaper for you. Newer technology brings better fuel efficiency, more reliability etc.

bad: if you end up driving to the drug store-medicine shop-chemist which is 5 minutes of walk from your house. When you don't carpool. When you over-speed, drink and drive, participate in illegal street racing (go become an F1- Nascar driver if you like to race and win), especially for pedestrians

Case 5: Robots and Machinery.
Good: Reduces human errors and fatality in hospitals, factories with dangerous work environments because they are robust and most reliable, have less fatigue compared to human counter parts.

Bad: Because it puts people out of jobs. Can be misused for thefts.

Case 6: Use of Technology in (bio)chemicals.
Good: Develops vaccines, medicines to tackle epidemics, malaria, common cold, HIV, Cancer and everything else. Bring artificial rain. Protecting crop harvest from pets and insects by developing pesticides. Higher durability varnish and paints, teflon, other hygroscopic materials and other things which will have extensive applications in future for many purposes currently unfathomable. and more.

Bad: Using technology to create bio-weapons, weapons of mass destruction (yes you can thank me President Obama) and more.


Each good and bad is dependent on how you think what is good and bad for you.

There is no single answer, neither a pure and emphatic YES nor a jubilant NO.

Why do Mormon temples have the Angel Moroni on top?

Not every temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints does have an angel Moroni statue on top, but most of them do. The second temple the Church completed, in Nauvoo, Illinois, featured an angel with a trumpet in a prone position, as though it was flying. It was placed on top of the temple’s tower, as a weather vane of sorts.

The next temple to feature an angel Moroni was the Salt Lake Temple, the fourth one completed after the Latter-day Saints arrived in Utah. (Temples in Utah that preceded it were built in St. George, Logan, and Manti.) It was placed on the capstone of the tallest tower, made of bronze with gold leaf, and standing in an upright pose. The statue was designed by Cyrus Dallin, who was a Utah native but not a member of the Church.

Five other temples were built after the Salt Lake Temple (in Laie, Hawaii; Cardston, Alberta; Mesa, Arozona; Idaho Falls, Idaho; and Bern, Switzerland) before another temple with a Moroni statue was built in Los Angeles, California.

Five more temples were built without Moroni statues (in Hamilton, New Zealand; London, England; Oakland, California; and Ogden and Provo, Utah) before the next Moroni statue was placed on top of the Washington, DC Temple. Since then, it has become something of a tradition to put Moroni statues on top of temples, including adding ones on some of the temples that were initially built without one. When the Nauvoo Temple was rebuilt, some question occurred about whether it should have an angel that resembled the one from the original structure, or if it should stand upright. It was ultimately decided to use an upright version, making it the most notable difference of the rebuilt temple’s exterior when compared to the original version.

The inspiration for putting an angel on top of temples comes from Revelation 14:6–7, which says,

And I saw another angel fly in the midst of heaven, having the everlasting gospel to preach unto them that dwell on the earth, and to every nation, and kindred, and tongue, and people,

Saying with a loud voice, Fear God, and give glory to him; for the hour of his judgment is come: and worship him that made heaven, and earth, and the sea, and the fountains of waters.

Latter-day Saints identify that angel as Moroni, due to the role he played as a resurrected being when directing Joseph Smith to discover and translate the gold plates he buried centuries earlier. The product of Joseph’s translation of the plates is the Book of Mormon, which contains the “everlasting gospel” for all people, and whose message is consistent with the message of the angel in Revelation.

How does the temple endowment benefit Mormons?

In the Book of Mormon studied by members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, both Lehi and his son Nephi have a vision of the tree of life. The vision is recorded in 1 Nephi chapter 8, and Nephi records the interpretation starting in chapter 11. I highly recommend you read these excellent chapters!

The tree of life and its amazing fruit are likened to the love of God. The rod of iron that people hold and follow to the tree is the word of God. By holding fast to the word of God, we are led to the tree and the love of God.

The temple endowment is a blessing of knowledge and covenan

In the Book of Mormon studied by members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, both Lehi and his son Nephi have a vision of the tree of life. The vision is recorded in 1 Nephi chapter 8, and Nephi records the interpretation starting in chapter 11. I highly recommend you read these excellent chapters!

The tree of life and its amazing fruit are likened to the love of God. The rod of iron that people hold and follow to the tree is the word of God. By holding fast to the word of God, we are led to the tree and the love of God.

The temple endowment is a blessing of knowledge and covenants that we make as individuals. It builds on and enhances the covenants we make when we are baptized. These covenants of keeping the commandments, sacrificing to build up the kingdom of God on the earth, and serving to help and lift others can help keep us holding fast to the iron rod, or the word of God, and help move us forward on the path to reaching the full love of God.

What is a sealing room in a Mormon temple?

It’s a room where husbands and wives and whole families are sealed for eternity. Eternal marriages take place in sealing rooms. If a couple is converted to the Church after being married in a civil ceremony or in another church, they will be sealed in the temple after a year. If they have children born before they are married in the temple, those children will also be sealed to them. Children born to a couple after they are married in the temple are automatically sealed to them since they are born under the marriage covenant.

Are children allowed in Mormon temples?

Yes, under strict rules. When the parents are being sealed, their living children are taken care of during the endowment session, then the children are brought up to the sealing room to be sealed to their parents after they have been sealed to each other. In adoption cases, the parents are already sealed and the children can be sealed to the parents after the adoption is final. This can be any child under the age of 18. If parents get sealed to each other when children are older than 18, those children are required to be Temple worthy and received his/her own endowment to represent themselves

Yes, under strict rules. When the parents are being sealed, their living children are taken care of during the endowment session, then the children are brought up to the sealing room to be sealed to their parents after they have been sealed to each other. In adoption cases, the parents are already sealed and the children can be sealed to the parents after the adoption is final. This can be any child under the age of 18. If parents get sealed to each other when children are older than 18, those children are required to be Temple worthy and received his/her own endowment to represent themselves in the sealing session.

There are other rules for youth for performing Baptisms for the dead. Young men and women who turn 12 during the calendar year can get a limited recommend for doing baptisms at the beginning of that year. They are allowed into the Baptistry area only

When was the first Mormon temple built?

The first Mormon Temple built was the Kirtland Temple in 1836. However, it is no longer currently an LDS temple or even part of the LDS history tour in Kirtland. It’s doesn’t even have the same features as a modern LDS temple. There is no baptistry, no area for endowments, no wedding ceremony area. It’s usage wasn’t that of a temple in modern times.

Why are Mormon temples so distinctive-looking?

Branding and function.

It’s no different from Jehovah’s Witness Halls, Masonic temples, and Catholic Cathedrals or McDonalds stores or gas stations.

There’s a certain expectation about temples, within and without the church. In one sense, they are just buildings with rooms, and there need to be so many rooms for this one to accommodate its needs, but on another point, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints uses these edifices to say to the world, “Here we are.” and, as each and every one of them says, “Holiness to the Lord.”

What are Mormon temple celebrations?

The temple in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is the pinnacle of our worship of Jesus Christ. In the temple, we make covenants with God that we will follow His Son Jesus Christ and commit our all to Him, and in return, God promises that we will receive the blessings of exaltation after the Second Coming of Christ.

The temple in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is the pinnacle of our worship of Jesus Christ. In the temple, we make covenants with God that we will follow His Son Jesus Christ and commit our all to Him, and in return, God promises that we will receive the blessings of exaltation after the Second Coming of Christ.

Sounds like a lot? It is. Making promises with God is no small matter. And the only place you can do that is in the temple. That’s why we celebrate: another House of the Lord for us to enter and sample what heaven will be like. Another place where we can experience part of what it will be like to be in God’s presence.

So we celebrate. We gather all the saints in the area where the temple is being constructed. We perform cultural dances and sing songs that remind us of the people who live in the area and how they now have local access to the House of the Lord. We praise the builders and those who will work and volunteer inside the temple. Finally, we dedicate the temple to the Lord, offering it to Him as a house where we can enter and be taught.

This shouldn’t be seen as weird. Just take a look at what goes on in your community all the time. People hold ribbon cuttings for new businesses and hospitals. We have grand openings for car dealerships and parties for new restaurants. It’s no strange thing to celebrate the opening of a new building that will benefit the residents of that area.

When a new literal house of God is finally ready for His people to enter, that they can learn how they can receive all the blessings He wants them to obtain in this life and the next, it rightfully should be the most important grand opening celebration of any building on Earth because of what it means for everyone: God lives; He loves all His children; He speaks to each of us individually; He sent His Son Jesus Christ to prepare us to return to God and become like Him; and the temple is where those truths are taught best.

Do Mormons want non-Mormons to be allowed into their temples?

Original question: Do Mormons want non-Mormons to be allowed into their temples?

We are no longer called “Mormons.” We are Latter-day Saints.

We have 31,315 congregations in all 50 states and every province of Canada and 151 other countries. You, your family, and anyone else has a standing invitation to come at any time. We have services every Sunday, and there is always a little more room in the pews. I don’t know any member of the Church who does not wish more people would come.

I apologize if there is any doubt that people aren’t welcome. We should think about sending people out to invite others, and maybe putting up some welcome signs.

Separate from the meetinghouse is the sacred space we call the temple. Entry there is not for us to decide. It is the Lord’s house, and He decides the entry requirements. Anyone who enters is a guest there.

Latter-day Saints derive a lot of joy from working and serving in the temple. We always get a little excited when someone comes to the temple for the first time because we get to share that joy.

Even when the temple isn’t dedicated, we love to welcome our non-member friends, relatives, neighbors, and coworkers to the Temple open house. I recently helped host one. We welcomed over 335,000 people and I described it here on Quora as one of the happiest moments of my life.

We don’t worry about meetinghouses or temples getting overcrowded. They’ll always build more.

Do Mormons keep their temples secret?

Original question: Do Mormons keep their temples secret?

No. At temple would be pretty hard to hide, don’t you think? We post their exterior and interior photos online. We post articles and videos about the reason we build temples. https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/temples/list?lang=eng

Before each temple is dedicated, there is an open house. All are invited. Visitors learn the purpose of each room and ask any questions they like. We hope they feel some of the holiness of this sacred place.

If you’re ever in the Washington DC area, please come by our temple’s visitors’ center. Maybe I’ll see you there.

Here’s a secret for you. We are no longer called “Mormons” except by the bigoted or ignorant. We are Latter-day Saints.

How many times can you renew your Mormon temple recommend?

Recommends to enter a temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints expire every two years. If one wishes to continue attending the temple, then one needs to meet with the bishop and stake president for a worthiness interview. Assuming one is deemed worthy of the privilege, the temple recommend will be reissued or renewed. There is no limit as to the number of times a temple recommend can be used or renewed throughout one’s life.

Are Mormon temples open to the public?

Only for “open houses” shortly before the temples are dedicated. Hundreds, if not thousands, of people, including Church members and non-members, come to tour the temples and see the incredibly majestic beauty of them before their doors are only open to Church members with current temple recommends.

However, non-members and members without recommends are allowed to wait in the lobbies during the performing of ordinance work by current temple recommend holders.

Are Mormon temples open during the week?

Temples of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints are generally open Tuesday through Saturday, with some breaks for holidays and vacations.

Hours are different right now due to COVID.

Each temple has a website explaining their days and hours of service.

Do Mormons have two different names for their temples?

Original question: Do Mormons have two different names for their temples?

We are not called “Mormons” anymore. We are Latter-day Saints.

We have two different kinds of houses of worship. One is the temple. The other is the meetinghouse. They are not the same. They are not interchangeable.

We sometimes call the temple the house of the Lord. That is what is engraved over the door. The temple is a holy place reserved for sacred ordinances performed by those who have prepared themselves spiritually. Some of the faithful make great sacrifices to be able to travel the temple once or twice in their live

Original question: Do Mormons have two different names for their temples?

We are not called “Mormons” anymore. We are Latter-day Saints.

We have two different kinds of houses of worship. One is the temple. The other is the meetinghouse. They are not the same. They are not interchangeable.

We sometimes call the temple the house of the Lord. That is what is engraved over the door. The temple is a holy place reserved for sacred ordinances performed by those who have prepared themselves spiritually. Some of the faithful make great sacrifices to be able to travel the temple once or twice in their lives.

This is the Bern Switzerland Temple. Inside the temple we wear white. This is not a meetinghouse.

We usually refer to the meetinghouse as the church, or sometimes the chapel. There are thousands of meetinghouses in over 100 countries, purposely built close to where people live. They are multipurpose structures for worship and other activities. In the meetinghouse we prepare ourselves to go to the temple. There is a new meetinghouse built on average every week. You are welcome to any of our meetinghouses any time you like.

This meetinghouse in Hermiston, Oregon is typical of the the newer meetinghouses. It’s not fancy, but it’s easily recognizable. It is not a temple.

We also pray in our homes.

Why are Mormon temples white?

Why are Mormon temples white?

Some temples are, indeed white. Some are brick. Some are inside, and a part, of other buildings such as the Hong Kong Temple and the one in New York City. Many of the Temples are grey, such as the famed Salt Lake City Temple. Below is a photo of one of newest Temple buildings that is to be dedicated very soon, Winnipeg Manitoba. Clearly it is not white.
